text: Estimating the cost of running a public-facing web site is the next and final step in
deploying a SharePoint Server farm in the Amazon Web Services cloud.
This video will show how to estimate the cost over time of running the sample public-facing
web site on the SharePoint Server farm deployed on AWS in the previous steps.
You may want to do this optional calculation after you’ve deployed your complete SharePoint site and have the final details,

but you can make a rough estimate at any 
point.
Hosting applications on Amazon Web Services offers significant savings over hosting them on-premises.
AWS provides you with the flexibility to choose between small, medium and large instance-type configurations.
And you can select a combination of On-Demand and Reserved Instances that matches your usage projections.
AWS offers Reserved Instance types from Light to Heavy Utilization that allow you to save more money as you get better usage data.
As traffic on the site rises or falls over time, you can scale up or down your configuration to match changing demand.
AWS has created a Simple Monthly Calculator at aws.amazon.com/calculator.
You input your capacity requirements and it estimates your costs.
We’ve provided a sample calculation for the SharePoint public-facing web site sample that assumes
3-Year Heavy Utilization Reserved Instances.
The companion document provides a link to it.
Under these assumptions, the monthly cost of running this sample site on AWS would be about $2,370.
Adding the one-time up-front payment, amortized over 3 years, the estimated total comes to roughly $3,250 per month.
This includes Windows and SQL Server licenses.
Assuming the architecture can support 500 concurrent users, the cost will be approximately $6.50 per user per month.
You should adjust these assumptions based on your own business requirements.
This video has covered estimating the cost of running a public-facing web site,
the final, optional step in deploying a SharePoint web site in the Amazon Web Services cloud.
